item.title: About Me...(Always Updated!) ‚ù§Ô∏è+ ‚òï + üïò
item.description: Can you hear me now?‚Ä¶Learning a programming language is interesting and fun at the same time, even more if you like to work with data. Unfortunately, it tends to fall into the erroneous idea that programming is only for those with a background in computing science and/or engineering, nevertheless, I think that programming is a multidisciplinary skill, where the only limitations are your own ideas. Hi! My name is Gabriel Cabrera and this is my little corner in this chaotic world.

item.title: Technical Analysis With Plotly
item.description: if(!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") p_load("plotly", "quantmod") get data GSPC <- getSymbols("^GSPC",src='yahoo',auto.assign = FALSE, from = "2007-01-01") df <- data.frame(Date=index(GSPC),coredata(GSPC)) create Bollinger Bands bbands <- BBands(GSPC[,c("GSPC.High","GSPC.Low","GSPC.Close")]) join and subset data df <- subset(cbind(df, data.frame(bbands[,1:3])), Date >= "2015-01-01") colors column for increasing and decreasing for (i in 1:length(df[,1])) { if (df$GSPC.Close[i] >= df$GSPC.Open[i]) { df$direction[i] = 'Aumento' } else { df$direction[i] = 'Disminuci√≥n' } } i <- list(line = list(color = '#17BECF')) d <- list(line = list(color = '#7F7F7F')) plot candlestick chart p <- df %>% plot_ly(x = ~Date, type="candlestick", open = ~GSPC.

item.title: How Install Julia in Bionic Beaver (Ubuntu 18.04)
One of the New Feature of ggplot2 3.0
item.description: Why this post? Some time ago Dina Pomeranz posted on twitter a brief article about how the gender gaps has been falling in most countries, if you don‚Äôt believe me: The unadjusted gender wage gap for full time workers has been falling significantly in most countries: https://t.co/k7olIo40ZA pic.twitter.com/uknetWXajw — Dina D. Pomeranz (@DinaPomeranz) July 4, 2018 After reading the post1, I decided to replicate the entire article using the new features of ggplot2 3.

item.title: T√≥picos en Econom√≠a & Negocios Utilizando R ‚û°Ô∏è üëΩ + üá™üá∏
item.description: Descripci√≥n Curso Este curso presenta una introducci√≥n a R, usando datos estructurados y no estructurados, relacionados a econom√≠a, finanzas y marketing. Entre los t√≥picos a discutir se encuentran: importaci√≥n y exportaci√≥n de datos en diferentes formatos, extracci√≥n de datos de sitios web, visualizaci√≥n de datos, regresi√≥n lineal, simulaci√≥n de Monte Carlo y construcci√≥n de aplicaciones web utilizando Shiny. Presentaciones Todas las presentaciones fueron confeccionadas usando la librer√≠a Xaringan de Yihui Xie con el tema Dharma-Xaringan, creado por m√≠ ‚úåÔ∏è (ver post).

item.title: Loops using R
item.description: Introduction Introduction this post has the intentionality to present briefly one of the property that exist in a ordinary square regression. if(!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") ## Loading required package: pacman p_load("tidyverse","gridExtra") set.seed(123) reps <- 10000 betas <- matrix(NA, nrow = reps, ncol = 2) beta0 <- 2 beta1 <- 2.5 beta2 <- 1 su = 2 n = c(100,1000) #tama√±o muestral for (j in 1:length(n)) { X1=rnorm(n[j],20,1) X2=runif(n[j],0,1) for (i in 1:reps) { u <- rnorm(n[j],0,su) Y <- beta0 + beta1*X1 + beta2*X2 + u model = lm(Y~X1) #Estima OLS - omite variable X2 betas[i,j] = model$coef[2] } } mean(betas[,1]) ## [1] 2.
